HOwDI
  • Running HOwDI Example/Tutorial
  • View page source

Running HOwDI Example/Tutorial

This page walks through a simple example of using HOwDI to determine the optimal infrastructure in a reduced version of Texas.

In this scenario, Dallas, Waco, Austin, Houston, and Freeport are the cities of interest. Freeport has an existing Steam Methane Reformer (SMR) and a pipeline to Houston. We would like to determine the optimal way to build hydrogen infrastructure given a potential demand.

Step 1: Preprocessing

As a first step, the initial data must be preprocessed to generate necessary input files. The preprocessing steps involve finding the geographic location of cities and determining the distance between them. These steps can be skipped if the necessary input files are already available.

  1. Create a hubs.csv file with the following columns:

    • hub: The name of the hub. This will be used to geocode the hub, so it should correspond to an actual city.

    • status: The “reach” of the hub. 1 corresponds to a major hub, -1 corresponds to a minor hub, and 0 corresponds to a regular hub. A major hub will be more likely to connect to other hubs than a regular hub will (an regular > minor).

    For this example, the hubs.csv file should look like:

    hubs.csv

    hub

    status

    austin

    0

    dallas

    1

    houston

    1

    freeport

    -1

    waco

    0

  2. Create arcs_whitelist.csv and arcs_blacklist.csv in the same directory. Both have columns startHub and endHub corresponding to the hubs that should or should not be forced to connect. arcs_whitelist.csv also contains a third column, exist_pipeline, which is True if there is an existing hydrogen pipeline that connects the hubs.

    For this example, the preprocessing code should connect Houston and Freeport, but we would like to specify that a pipeline exists. The preprocessing code may also connect Dallas and Austin, which is unnecessary since any route from Dallas to Austin must go through Waco.

    arcs_whitelist.csv

    startHub

    endHub

    exist_pipeline

    houston

    freeport

    1
    arcs_blacklist.csv

    startHub

    endHub

    austin

    dallas

  3. The preprocessing code can be run from the directory containing the three generated files. We’ll add other parameters to create a figure.

    HOwDI create_hub_data -f -shp US_COUNTY_SHPFILE/US_county_cont.shp

The following file is generated:

arcs.csv

endHub

kmLength_road

0

0

99.1198

1

houston

261.16592973831126

0

0

0

Additionally, for generating output figures, fig.png, hubs.geojson, and roads.csv are generated. These files are not necessary to run the HOwDI model, but are useful for visualizing the results.

hubs.geojson
{
    "type": "FeatureCollection",
    "crs": { "type": "name", "properties": { "name": "urn:ogc:def:crs:OGC:1.3:CRS84" } },
    "features": [
        { "type": "Feature", "properties": { "hub": "austin", "address": "Austin, Travis County, Texas, United States", "County": "Travis County" }, "geometry": { "type": "Point", "coordinates": [ -97.7436995, 30.2711286 ] } },
        { "type": "Feature", "properties": { "hub": "dallas", "address": "Dallas, Dallas County, Texas, United States", "County": "Dallas County" }, "geometry": { "type": "Point", "coordinates": [ -96.7968559, 32.7762719 ] } },
        { "type": "Feature", "properties": { "hub": "houston", "address": "Houston, Harris County, Texas, United States", "County": "Harris County" }, "geometry": { "type": "Point", "coordinates": [ -95.3676974, 29.7589382 ] } },
        { "type": "Feature", "properties": { "hub": "freeport", "address": "Freeport, Brazoria County, Texas, 77541, United States", "County": "Brazoria County" }, "geometry": { "type": "Point", "coordinates": [ -95.3596617, 28.9541368 ] } },
        { "type": "Feature", "properties": { "hub": "waco", "address": "Waco, McLennan County, Texas, United States", "County": "McLennan County" }, "geometry": { "type": "Point", "coordinates": [ -97.1474628, 31.5491899 ] } }
    ]
}

Step 2: Generating Inputs

Inputs for the HOwDI model can be placed anywhere. Create a directory corresponding to the scenario, and create an inputs directory within that. The output directory will be created automatically within this scenario directory.

For more detail on the inputs, see inputs.

The following input files are required for the HOwDI model:

  • arcs.csv: distances between hubs (generated in the previous step, no additional data required)

  • ccs.csv: parameters and costs for retrofitting existing SMRs with CCS

  • conversion.csv: parameters and costs for conversion technologies (liquefaction, compression, terminals, fuel dispensers, purification)

  • demand.csv: demand sector descriptions

  • hubs.csv: name of each each hub, ability to build infrastructure, and demand per demand sector

  • production_electric.csv: parameters and costs for electrolysis and other electric production technologies

  • production_existing.csv: parameters, costs, and hubs for existing SMRs

  • production_thermal.csv: parameters and costs for thermal production technologies (SMR)

  • settings.yml: settings for the model

arcs.csv

This file is generated in the previous step. No additional data are required.

arcs.csv

startHub

endHub

kmLength_euclid

kmLength_road

ccs.csv

This file contains the parameters and costs for retrofitting existing SMRs with CCS. It currently only supports the use of two CCS retrofit technologies aptly named ccs1 and ccs2. The model will choose to build or or none of these for existing SMRs.

ccs.csv

type

variable_usdPerTonCO2

percent_CO2_captured

h2_tax_credit

ccs1

50

0.6

459

ccs2

70

0.9

689

conversion.csv

This file describes conversion steps that occur between production, distribution, and demand, and the associated costs.

Warning

Adding or subtracting converters from the converter index or changing arc_start_class and arc_end_class is only for advanced users.

demand.csv

This file describes the price a consumer is willing to pay for hydrogen in each demand sector (breakevenPrice), wether or not the demand sector is carbon sensitive (CHECs), the amount of carbon emissions avoided by switching to a hydrogen for a demand sector, and the demand type (lowPurity, highPurity, or fuelStation).

hubs.csv

This file describes which hubs are used by the model, if a technology can be built at that hub (build_<tech>, binary), the demand per demand sector at that hub (<demandSector>_tonnesperday, where <demandSector> is defined in demand.csv), and the hub’s natural gas price, electricity price, and capital price multiplier.

production_electric.csv

This file describes the cost of building and operating electric production infrastructure, size restrictions, tax credits, and the carbon intensity of the electricity used. Since HOwDI does not have a time domain, utilization refers to the fraction of the time (day) that the technology is operating.

production_electric.csv

fixed_usdPerTon

capEx_$_per_kW

production_existing.csv

This file describes existing production capacity. The type column corresponds to a thermal producer defined in production_thermal.csv. The hub is the location, and capacity_tonPerDay is the existing capacity. The columns can_ccs1 and can_ccs2 are binaries allowing the addition of CCS to the existing SMR.

production_existing.csv

type

hub

capacity_tonPerDay

fixed_usdPerTonPerDay

capital_usdPerTonPerDay

ng_mmbtu_per_tonH2

variable_usdPerTon

co2_emissions_per_h2_tons

can_ccs1

can_ccs2

0

production_thermal.csv

Similar to other production files, this file describes the costs associated with building and operating thermal production infrastructure.

Note

Although the zeros in the build_smr-noCCS column of hubs.csv prevent the model from building this type of CCS, this “type” is used in the production_existing.csv, indicating that the prices in production_thermal.csv are used.

settings.yml

The settings file specifies any options outside of the scope of the other input files.

The only setting that may need to be changed now is solver_settings/solver.

settings.yml
# Price tracking settings
find_prices: True # True: Use price tracking feature
price_tracking_array:
  start: 1
  stop: 10
  step: 0.05
price_hubs: all
#["austin", "pasadena"] # "all"
price_demand: 1.0E-5

# Carbon settings, should maybe be a csv file
carbon_price_dollars_per_ton: 0
carbon_capture_credit_dollars_per_ton: 50
baseSMR_CO2_per_H2_tons: 9 # the co2 mass per h2 mass that defines 0 CHECs.

# Subsidy settings, should maybe be a csv file
subsidy_dollar_billion: 0
subsidy_cost_share_fraction: 0.9

# Investment settings, should maybe be a csv file
investment_interest: 0.06
investment_period: 20
time_slices: 365

# percent of capital used to estimate fixed costs
fixedcost_percent: 0.02

# Solver settings
solver_settings:
  solver: "gurobi"
  solver_debug: False
  mipgap: 1.0E-2

# other options
fractional_chec: True # True - CHECs are assigned based on carbon free hydrogen, False - CHECs are given for all production if producer has any form of carbon reduction

# optional options
# hubs_dir: C:\\path\\to\\hubs\\directory\\where hubs.geojson, roads.csv, etc. are stored
# otherwise, uses what is specified in data/data_mapping.yml

Step 3: Running the Model

Navigate to the “scenario” directory that is above/contains the “inputs” directory.

ls
> /inputs

Run the model with the following command:

HOwDI run

Step 4: Outputs and Viewing Results

The model will generate a directory called “outputs” in the scenario directory. This directory contains the following files:

  • production.csv: production infrastructure built

  • distribution.csv: distribution infrastructure built

  • consumption.csv: demand met and theoretical delivered prices

  • conversion.csv: conversion infrastructure built

  • fig.png: a figure showing the infrastructure built

  • outputs.json: A JSON file containing all the outputs in a single file

outputs/production.csv

This file describes the production infrastructure built by the model. In this case, the model decided to add CCS2 to the existing SMR in Freeport, and build electrolyzers in Freeport and Waco.

outputs/distribution.csv

This file describes the distribution infrastructure built by the model. In this case, the existing pipeline is utilized and new pipelines transport hydrogen from Waco to Austin and Dallas.

This file can be better understood by looking at fig.png or using the HOwDI traceback or HOwDI traceforward commands.

outputs/consumption.csv

This file describes the demand met by the model. There are also very small demands that are met to determine the price-nodes price. In this demonstrative case, all demand is met, and hydrogen can be delivered to fuel stations for just above $2/kg.

outputs/fig.png

This file is a figure showing the infrastructure built by the model. Hydrogen is produced in electrolysis Waco, consumed locally, and transported to Dallas and Austin via pipeline. Hydrogen is also produced in Freeport, consumed locally, and transported to Houston via pipeline.

outputs/outputs.json

This file contains all the outputs in a single file, which is useful for some data manipulation.

outputs.json (first few lines)
{
    "austin": {
        "production": {},
        "conversion": {
            "fuelDispenserPipeline": {
                "conv_capacity": 590.0026333333334,
                "conv_cost_capital": 3498375.598079648,
                "conv_cost_fixed": 1452.1391388,
                "conv_cost_variable": 0,
                "conv_e_price": 85.28213922,
                "conv_utilization": 0.6,
                "fuelStation_cost_capital_subsidy": 206405081.5256067
            }
        },
        "consumption": {
            "demandSector_transportationFuel_carbonSensitive": {
                "cons_carbonSensitive": 1,
                "cons_h": 354.0,
                "cons_checs": 354.0,
                "cons_price": 5000.0,
                "cons_size": 354.0
            },

Step 5: Further result analysis

The HOwDI traceback and HOwDI traceforward commands can be used to trace the flow of hydrogen through the network.

Using HOwDI traceforward, we can see that hydrogen from freeport is consumed locally and transported to Houston via pipeline.

howdi traceforward --hub freeport

origin-freeport (0.00*100.00%=0.00)
├── origin-electrolyzer-RE (0.00 -> 897.00, 897.00*51.64%=463.20)
│   └── freeport-production_electrolyzer-RE_TO_center_highPurity (463.20*100.00%=463.20)
│       └── freeport-center_highPurity_TO_dist_pipelineHighPurity (463.20*100.00%=463.20)
│           ├── freeport-dist_pipelineHighPurity_TO_demand_lowPurity (463.20*22.50%=104.20)
│           │   └── freeport-demand_lowPurity_TO_demandSector_existing (104.20 -> 538.00, 538.00*100.00%=538.00)
│           │       └── freeport-demandSector_existing (538.00*100.00%=538.00)
│           └── freeport-dist_pipelineHighPurity_TO_houston_dist_pipelineHighPurity (463.20*77.50%=359.00)
│               └── houston-dist_pipelineHighPurity_TO_converter_fuelDispenserPipeline (359.00*100.00%=359.00)
│                   └── houston-converter_fuelDispenserPipeline_TO_demand_fuelStation (359.00*100.00%=359.00)
│                       └── houston-demand_fuelStation_TO_demandSector_transportationFuel_carbonSensitive (359.00 -> 359.00, 359.00*100.00%=359.00)
│                           └── houston-demandSector_transportationFuel_carbonSensitive (359.00*100.00%=359.00)
└── origin-smr-noCCSExisting (0.00 -> 897.00, 897.00*48.36%=433.80)
    └── freeport-production_smr-noCCSExisting_TO_center_lowPurity (433.80*100.00%=433.80)
        └── freeport-center_lowPurity_TO_dist_pipelineLowPurity (433.80*100.00%=433.80)
            └── freeport-dist_pipelineLowPurity_TO_demand_lowPurity (433.80*100.00%=433.80)
                └── freeport-demand_lowPurity_TO_demandSector_existing (433.80 -> 538.00, 538.00*100.00%=538.00)
                    └── freeport-demandSector_existing (538.00*100.00%=538.00)

Note

Production numbers can sometimes seem off, but this is a result of utilization. For instance, the existing steam methane reformer in Freeport is producing 433.80 tonnes of hydrogen, but the capacity in production_existing.csv is 482 tonnes. However, the utilization of this SMR is 0.9, so the actual production is capacity times utilization, 482*0.9 = 433.80.
